newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission urges EU role in fighting child trade.
newsitem.headline: Commission urges EU role in fighting child trade.

text.p: The European Commission urged EU member states on Wednesday to set aside doubts about the Union's role in fighting cross-border crime in the interests of stamping out the sex trade in children and women.

Ahead of a two-day gathering of EU justice ministers in Dublin, commissioners stressed at their weekly meeting that the Union had a crucial coordinating role in combating the vice trade, spokesman Nikolaus van der Pas told reporters.
The issue has been thrown into the world spotlight by a Belgian child murder and sex scandal.
The Commission's call was backed by Ireland, which as EU president will host the meeting, starting on Thursday.

European Union member states, jealous of their own police and judicial systems, have so far been reluctant to extend the EU's competence to fighting cross-border crime, which also involves drugs, cars and nuclear materials and money laundering.
"Without these kinds of cooperation, the calls of many...for action to be taken cannot be met in an effective way," Irish Justice Minister Nora Owen told a European Parliament committee on Wednesday.
The bodies of two young Belgian girls, kidnapped from their Liege homes in June 1995, were found in August in a property owned by a convicted rapist in south Belgium. They had been starved to death.
The bodies of two other young women, abducted in August 1995 from the Belgian seaside town of Ostend, were found on another property associated with the man three weeks ago.
Two other girls were rescued, and the ensuing investigation revealed links between the Belgian ring and the Czech Republic and Slovakia and links with trafficking in stolen cars.
Officials believe the fate of the four girls exposes a deeper problem of international trafficking in kidnapped children, discussed at a world conference in Stockholm in August.
The Dublin meeting will examine an action plan by Belgium's Justice Minister Stefaan de Clerck to harmonise criminal and procedural law and legal cooperation at an international level.
It would also involve exchange and training of vice squad staffs and creating a directory of police expertise.

At the meeting, Justice Commissioner Anita Gradin will outline the Commission's work to date on fighting trade in women and children and urge EU members to ratify a convention that will fully deploy the EU's police agency Europol.

Ireland wants agreement at the meeting on a plan to expand the role of Europol to specifically fight the trade in people. This would involve setting up a central database of missing children, as demanded by the European Parliament.
"Without international cooperation a comprehensive list of missing children cannot be drawn up," said Owen.
